title: Behavioural Economics Cambridge Tradition 2024
text:
“We think, each of us, that we’re much more rational than we are.”
– Daniel Kahneman


“The purely economic man is indeed close to being a social moron. Economic theory has been much preoccupied with this rational fool.”
– Amartya Sen


Overview

In recent decades, economics has increasingly relied on quantitative models to understand and explore economic phenomena. Central to many of these models is the idea that agents act as rational beings and make rational choices. The emergence of behavioural economics is contextualized as a question of validity to such assumptions and a response to addressing some critical problems that irrationality raises in economic modelling. Integral to this endeavor is understanding the difference between homo-economicus (the economic man) and homo-sapiens (real humans). It is crucial to understand why economic models that assume agents behave as homo-economicus often fail in real life.
The course aims to start from the core assumptions which are often made in economics and then moves on to systematically understand why these are flawed. We then discuss some of the core themes and concepts in behavioural economics. The course aims to explain all these topics using real world examples to show why behavioural economics makes a difference. We then cover the role of behavioural economics in different areas beyond economics.

Assessment

Students will be split into groups of 2-3 and will be required to research into any industry/theme of their choosing seeing how behavioural economics is used in that industry. The students will be evaluated based on their presentations of their research in class and a short writeup that would be submitted to the instructor about their research.

title: Day 2: Into the World of (ir)Rationality
text:
Overview

Rationality is one of the most over-used words in economics and a recurring assumption in a lot of influential models in the discipline. Assuming that agents seek to maximize their benefit appears at first glance to be intuitive and even reasonable. However a careful peeling away of the layers of what rationality means leads to the unraveling of some of these models. This lecture introduces this tenet of economics and marks the beginning of our two week journey of exploring the depths of nuance this over-used word holds.
The slides for this lecture can be found here: Into the World of (ir)Rationality
